Expectation1: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation1: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A long-time congregant requested a private meeting soon because of mounting family stress.
Story: As I stood before the jury, carefully explaining the legal standards that would guide their deliberations, my clerk slipped me a note. My heart skipped. The Supreme Court had just overturned the very precedent I was referencing. I paused, feeling the weight of my robe and the eyes of the courtroom on me. I knew I had to stop and reconsider my instructions, to stay true to the law and my duty as a judge. Yet, my phone vibrated in my pocket—a message from a long-time congregant, pleading for a meeting tonight. He was struggling, his family on the brink, and he needed my guidance as his imam. The courtroom demanded my immediate attention, but so did my community. I felt torn, the expectations of impartial justice clashing with the call to provide comfort and counsel. My mind raced, caught between the urgency of legal change and the quiet desperation of a soul in need.
